citations.narrative:
On 7/25/2023, a small boy was bit by a 3 year old intact male wallaby, Gustave, while in the pen with the wallaby. The
skin was not broken, and the boy was examined by a doctor, but no treatment was required. The wallaby was examined
by the attending veterinarian and placed under a ten-day quarantine, and both intact male wallabys were subsequently
neutered. Guests are no longer allowed in the wallaby pens.
Animals must be handled so that there is minimal risk to the animal and the public to prevent harm or injury to the human
or animal.
Corrected by the time of inspection.

The bottom of the cage containing 3 long haired guinea pigs had no clean bedding and was completely covered in
pulverized fecal material and old bedding. A build up of fecal material can increase disease risk in these animals. Primary
enclosures for guinea pigs must be cleaned and sanitized as often as necessary but at least every two weeks to prevent
accumulation of fecal material or debris.
To be corrected by 12/5/2023.

The fence between one year old camel and two pigs had poles that were leaning and panels that did not connect as well
as woven wire panels with sharp points and edges protruding into the space at head and knee levels. These sharp points
and edges could cause injuries to the animals and the fence structural strength was not adequate to contain large
animals.
All fencing and facilities must be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals.

The skunk housed indoors in a wire crate had a large amount of crusted material containing hair and debris stuck to the
wires of the cage. Large amounts of dirt and debris were on the floor outside of the cage. Dirt and debris can cause odors
and increase disease and pest infestation hazards for the animals. All enclosures must be completely cleaned to remove
hair, fecal material, dirt and debris to minimize odor and disease/pest infestation risk.
To be corrected by 12/5/2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
On 7/25/2023, a small boy was bit by a 3 year old intact male wallaby, Gustave, while in the pen with the wallaby. The 
skin was not broken, and the boy was examined by a doctor, but no treatment was required. The wallaby was examined 
by the attending veterinarian  and placed under a ten-day quarantine, and both intact male wallabys were subsequently 
neutered. Guests are no longer allowed in the wallaby pens. 
Animals must be handled so that there is minimal risk to the animal and the public to prevent  harm or injury to the human 
or animal. 
Corrected by the time of inspection. 
3.31(a) 
   
Sanitation. 
The bottom of the cage containing 3 long haired guinea pigs had no clean bedding and was completely covered  in 
pulverized  fecal material and old bedding. A build up of fecal material can increase disease risk in these animals. Primary 
enclosures for guinea pigs must be cleaned and sanitized as often as necessary but at least every two weeks to prevent 
accumulation of fecal material or debris. 
To be corrected by 12/5/2023. 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
The fence between one year old camel and two pigs had poles that were leaning and panels that did not connect as well 
as woven wire panels with sharp points and edges protruding into the space at head and knee levels. These sharp points 
and edges could cause injuries to the animals and the fence structural strength was not adequate to contain large 
animals. 
All fencing and facilities must be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals. 
3.131(a) 
   
Sanitation.

The skunk housed indoors in a wire crate had a large amount of crusted material containing hair and debris stuck to the 
wires of the cage. Large amounts of dirt and debris were on the floor outside of the cage. Dirt and debris can cause odors 
and increase disease and pest infestation hazards for the animals. All enclosures must be completely cleaned to remove 
hair, fecal material, dirt and debris to minimize odor and disease/pest infestation risk. 
To be corrected by 12/5/2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative.
